channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/Reuters
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: Honda Hackers May Have Used Tools Favored by Countries
item.description: A recent cyberattack that disrupted the operations of the company may have been the first time criminals used sophisticated software previously known to be used by state agents.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Roman Pilipey/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Honda says it has resumed production at its factories after its computer systems were disrupted by a virus.

item.title: Vicki Wood, Who Broke Car-Racing Gender Barriers, Dies at 101
item.description: A trailblazer in a macho world, she burned up the sand at Daytona Beach, clocking in at more than 150 miles per hour.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.category: National Assn of Stock Car Auto Racing
item.media:credit: ISC Images & Archives, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vicki Wood at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida in 1959, the year it opened. She was among the first women to compete in NASCAR events.

item.title: A Model for the ‘Dance World We Want’
item.description: Melanie Greene and J. Bouey, hosts of the Dance Union podcast, are moving beyond “a lot of talking” to organize for change.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Burke
item.media:credit: Left, Brad Ogbonna for The New York Times; Right, Kennedi Carter for The New York Times
item.media:description: J. Bouey and Melanie Greene, hosts of the Dance Union podcast. Their second town hall will focus on dance education, mental health and organizing demonstrations.

item.title: One Big Difference About George Floyd Protests: Many White Faces
item.description: Early demographic data shows a significant presence of white protesters.
item.dc:creator: Amy Harmon and Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Amir Hamja for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered outside of Brooklyn Borough Hall in New York last week to protest the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Rubber Bullets and Beanbag Rounds Can Cause Devastating Injuries
item.description: Common crowd-dispersal methods used on protesters across the country have caused brain damage and other disabilities, prompting growing calls to ban them.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh and David Montgomery
item.media:credit: Ricardo B. Brazziell/Austin American-Statesman, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A protester injured in Austin, Texas, on May 30.

item.title: Mutation Allows Coronavirus to Infect More Cells, Study Finds. Scientists Urge Caution.
item.description: Geneticists said more evidence is needed to determine if a common genetic variation of the virus spreads more easily between people.
item.dc:creator: Benedict Carey and James Glanz

item.title: Court Seems Open to Allowing Judge to Scrutinize Bid to Drop Flynn Case
item.description: An appeals court panel’s questions suggested that it is unlikely to block a lower-court judge from examining why prosecutors asked to dismiss the case against a Trump ally who already pleaded guilty.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Joshua Roberts/Reuters
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, twice pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I.

item.title: In Bitter Kentucky G.O.P. Primary, Thomas Massie and Todd McMurtry Trade Charges of Racism
item.description: Representative Thomas Massie and his Republican primary challenger have made race and racism a central focus weeks before Election Day in an increasingly ugly contest.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Thomas Massie, Republican of Kentucky, is defending his seat in the most expensive Republican House primary in Kentucky history.

item.title: Your 2020 Virtual Pride Event Guide
item.description: L.G.B.T.Q. Pride events will look and feel very different this year, but many are still on — online. Here are some of the most notable, with details on when and how to tune in.
item.dc:creator: Maya Salam
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman/The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrations from last year’s 50th anniversary of the Stonewall uprising.

item.title: The Latest Police Tool in Protests: Paintball Guns
item.description: They are essentially no different than the ones used recreationally, but the projectiles carry hidden risks when fired at unsuspecting people who lack the protective gear that gamers use.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Police in riot gear and armed with shields and paintball guns as demonstrators gathered to protest the death of George Floyd last month in Washington.

item.title: In Fine Print, Airlines Make It Harder to Fight for Passenger Rights
item.description: An increasing number of airlines are adding clauses that require passengers to settle disputes in private arbitration, rather than in court, and bar passengers from starting or joining class-action lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Firshein
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Free antibacterial wipes are now available at LaGuardia Airport. Along with a new terminal at the New York City airport, there are many new changes to air travel across the globe.

item.title: New Breonna Taylor Law Will Ban No-Knock Warrants in Louisville, Ky.
item.description: The Louisville Metro Council voted unanimously to ban no-knock search warrants after the police shot Ms. Taylor dead in her home in March.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Christine Hauser
item.media:credit: Erik Branch for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural in Louisville, Ky., depicting George Floyd and Breonna Taylor. Mr. Floyd died in police custody in Minneapolis in May, and Ms. Taylor was killed by the police in March.

item.title: Trump’s Actions Rattle the Military World: ‘I Can’t Support the Man’
item.description: The president’s threat to use troops against largely peaceful protesters, as well as other attempts to politicize the military, have unsettled a number of current and former members and their families.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Erin Fangmann, whose husband is in the Air Force, said that she had voted Republican all her life, but that President Trump had “hurt the military.”

item.title: Live Updates on George Floyd Protests: Cuomo Signs Police Misconduct Bills
item.description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York signed an expansive package of bills aimed at combating police misconduct, endorsing a major overhaul of law enforcement.
item.media:credit: Scott Heins/Getty Images

item.title: PG&E Gives Wildfire Victims More Stock in Bankruptcy Plan
item.description: The company is increasing the number of shares it will give homeowners and businesses that lost properties during fires caused by its equipment.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Ben Margot/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pacific Gas & Electric said it would give victims of wildfires caused by its equipment more than 22 percent of its stock as part of the company’s plan to resolve its bankruptcy.

item.title: How Many Homeless People Live in L.A.? What One Count Tells Us
item.description: Friday: The pandemic and a more urgent focus on systemic racism have created opportunities, but also highlighted the depth of the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press
item.media:description: A woman walked past a homeless man napping on the street amid the coronavirus pandemic in the Westlake neighborhood of Los Angeles last month.

item.title: Both Candidates Are Widely Disliked (Again). This Time, Biden Could Benefit.
item.description: This could be the second straight presidential contest in which both candidates are viewed negatively by a majority of voters. But now that dynamic appears to hurt Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times; Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Among ambivalent voters who see both candidates unfavorably, Joseph R. Biden Jr. has a considerable edge over President Trump.

item.title: Kamala Harris, Front-runner (Again)
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris in Des Moines, Iowa, in November.

item.title: Coronavirus Updates and Live News
item.description: Counties that include Houston and Dallas have logged some of the nation’s largest single-day rises. Canada may give special attention to asylum cases of people who are working as caregivers in the pandemic.
item.media:credit: Lynne Sladky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Medical workers registering people at a testing site in Miami in May.

item.title: For George Floyd’s Mourners, What Does ‘Justice’ Mean?
item.description: Democrats are decrying the problem of “systemic racism.” But to many, the policy solutions seem to leave the system intact.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the more than two weeks since he died, “Justice for George Floyd” has become an omnipresent mantra, but there remains little agreement on what that would mean from a public policy perspective.

item.title: Do Police Officers Make Schools Safer or More Dangerous?
item.description: School resource officers were supposed to prevent mass shootings and juvenile crime. But some schools are eliminating them amid a clamor from students after George Floyd’s death.
item.dc:creator: Dana Goldstein
item.category: National Assn of School Resource Officers
item.media:credit: Bethany Mollenkof for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadera Powell, 17, said seeing officers in the hallways at her school in Los Angeles sent a clear message to black students: “We have you on watch. We are able to take legal or even physical action against you.”

item.title: After Virtual Graduation, Protesting for Their Lives
item.description: Graduates from around the nation, some in their caps and gowns, have gone to protests after their online ceremonies to make a statement.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia

item.title: Korean Adoptee Wins Landmark Case in Search for Birth Parents
item.description: In the first verdict of its kind, a South Korean court has ruled that Kara Bos, an American, is a daughter of an 85-year-old man in Seoul.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: Kara Bos speaking in front of a court in Seoul, South Korea, after her trial on Friday.

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker and Economy Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Lucas Jackson/Reuters
item.media:description: Investors were confronted with more warnings about the pace of economic recovery.

item.title: These Are the 10 U.S. Army Installations Named for Confederates
item.description: A debate is unfolding over whether to rename the installations, as part of a broader national reckoning over buildings, monuments and memorials to men who fought to preserve slavery and uphold white supremacy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: © Corbis/Corbis, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. John Hood

item.title: As Public Opinion Shifts on Racism, Trump Digs In
item.description: With much of the country acknowledging that protesters’ frustrations are justified, the president increasingly sounds detached from many voters in the political middle and even some of his allies.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin, Maggie Haberman and Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has suggested siccing dogs on protesters and has defended the Confederate names of military installations.

item.title: Moving Beyond ‘MAGA’?
item.description: Can a campaign of nostalgia work as more Americans recognize the racial injustices of the past?
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Ambush Suspect Is Killed After Wounding 3 Officers in a Standoff, Sheriff Says
item.description: Mason James Lira, 26, who shot a deputy in the face outside a police station in Paso Robles, Calif., early Wednesday, was surrounded by officers in a vineyard on Thursday, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: David Middlecamp/The Tribune (of San Luis Obispo), via Associated Press
item.media:description: The authorities investigated the fatal shooting of a man in Paso Robles, Calif., on Wednesday. The suspect later shot a sheriff’s deputy, the police say.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Doctors and researchers are making headway on potential treatments for Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: She Witnessed the Pandemic’s Toll From Inside a Funeral Home
item.description: Stephanie Garcia, as one of the last responders on the front lines, worked quietly and tirelessly in the background as the number of bodies piled up.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

item.title: Former D.E.A. Spokesman Pleads Guilty to $4.4 Million Fraud
item.description: Garrison Kenneth Courtney pretended to be a C.I.A. officer to bilk companies.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: C-SPAN
item.media:description: Garrison Kenneth Courtney, a former Drug Enforcement Administration spokesman, in 2004. He pleaded guilty on Thursday to wire fraud.

item.title: Georgia Havoc Raises New Doubts on Pricey Voting Machines
item.description: Long before this week’s election chaos, experts had warned Georgia about its over $100 million voting system, saying paper ballots were simpler and safer.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Poll workers were unable to sync voting machines and had to hand out provisional ballots on Tuesday at Coan Park Recreation Center in Atlanta.

item.title: What Does It Mean to Tear Down a Statue?
item.description: We asked an art historian who studies the destruction of cultural heritage.
item.dc:creator: Jonah Engel Bromwich
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters throwing the statue of the slave trader Edward Colston into a harbor last Sunday.

item.title: Defying Trump, Senate Panel Moves to Strip Military Bases of Confederate Names
item.description: Inclusion of the measure in a sweeping annual defense bill, which Republicans supported, raises the prospect of an election-year Senate vote on whether to honor Confederate figures.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Jonathan Drake/Reuters
item.media:description: Soldiers at Fort Bragg in North Carolina, which is named after a Confederate general, Braxton Bragg.
